channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chinese-Style Suit for Xi Jinping’s European Trip
item.description: Chinese citizens who are used to their leaders’ sartorial decisions being a model of suit-and-tie uniformity were surprised to see President Xi Jinping wearing a modified Mao suit in Amsterdam.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and his wife, Peng Liyuan, left, met with King Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands, Queen Maxima and Princess Beatrix, right, at the Royal Palace in Amsterdam on Saturday.

item.title: Russia Is Ousted From Group of 8 by U.S. and Allies
item.description: The move will at least temporarily end Russia’s two-decade participation in the diplomatic forum, and it was intended as a signal of the West’s condemnation of Russian actions in Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama spoke Monday at the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam in front of the Rembrandt painting “The Night Watch.”

item.title: India Ink: Why I Won’t Run for Office in India This Time
item.description: The author finds one simple explanation for his reluctance to participate in politics: fear.
item.dc:creator: By DILIP D'SOUZA

item.title: Australia Suspends Search for Jet Debris, Citing Bad Weather
item.description: “Horrendous” conditions delayed the search Tuesday, as airline officials warned the passengers’ family members that they should accept the deaths of their loved ones.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Speaking at Kuala Lumpur International Airport on Tuesday, Malaysia Airlines chief executive Ahmad Jauhari Yahya, left, and chairman Nor Yusof said that the relatives of the passengers and crew must accept that their loved ones had almost certainly died.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ex-Bloomberg Editor Tells Why He Left
item.description: Ben Richardson, a former senior Bloomberg News editor based in Hong Kong, was involved in the editing of a story last year on China’s wealthiest man that was not published, following a discussion among the company’s top executives.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Broadcasts of Bloomberg Television being displayed on screens in the financial district of Hong Kong.

item.title: Ebola, Killing Scores in Guinea, Threatens Nearby Nations
item.description: At least 59 people have died of Ebola fever in Guinea, including some workers who treated early cases. The virus has mostly appeared in border areas of the West African nation.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Reporter Denied Saudi Visa
item.description: The Washington bureau chief of The Jerusalem Post has been denied a visa to Saudi Arabia to report on President Obama’s visit to that country, the newspaper reported on Monday.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: 22 Soldiers Killed by Militants
item.description: Militants killed 22 soldiers at a security checkpoint in southeastern Yemen on Monday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Pistorius Trial Hears Texts
item.description: Oscar Pistorius, the South African double-amputee athlete, and his girlfriend argued fiercely in the weeks before he killed her last year, according to text messages revealed at his murder trial.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Uganda: Dozens Die After Boat Capsizes
item.description: The death toll from a boat accident on Lake Albert in western Uganda has reached 107, Ugandan police said Monday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: N.B.A. Denies Clearing Nets to Become ‘Russian’
item.description: The Nets owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov spoke Monday of a desire to turn the team into the legal equivalent of a Russian one, but the N.B.A. denied receiving an application to transfer ownership.
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD SANDOMIR
item.media:description: Russian President Vladimir Putin, left, and Mikhail Prokhorov, president of the Russian Biathlon Union All-Russian Public Organization, during a state awards presentation ceremony in the Kremlin in Moscow, on Monday.

item.title: Jet Fell Into Ocean With All Lost, Premier Says
item.description: Based on analysis of satellite data, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia said there was no longer any doubt that the plane flew south into remote waters and could not have landed safely.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 in Beijing.

item.title: Listening Post: Obama Juggles Itinerary in Bid to Ease Tensions Between Two Asian Allies
item.description: An unusual effort by the administration to bring together the estranged leaders of Japan and South Korea has included changes in travel plans and a meeting at The Hague.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at a news conference on sales taxes in Tokyo last year.

item.title: Hundreds of Egyptians Sentenced to Death in Killing of a Police Officer
item.description: The conviction of 529 detainees accelerated the crackdown against Islamist supporters of Mohammed Morsi, the ousted president.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Relatives of the supporters of ousted Egyptian president Mohamed Morsi reacted to news of the verdict outside the courthouse in Minya, Egypt, on Monday.

item.title: Venezuela Takes Steps to Ease Curbs on Currency
item.description: Trying to curb a ballooning black market, the government said it will ease currency controls to bring down the cost of the dollar.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Uganda’s Anti-Gay Law Complicates U.S. Aid in Rebel Hunt
item.description: President Obama has come under criticism from human rights groups for using President Yoweri Museveni as an ally on security issues.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:description: An American Special Forces officer, in sunglasses, spoke with Africans and others seeking Joseph Kony in Obo, Central African Republic, last April.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese ‘NGO’ Member Barred From United Nations
item.description: The barring from a United Nations meeting of a member of a prominent Chinese non-governmental organization, in reality a group with ties to the highest levels of the government, casts a spotlight on China’s “GONGOs”; government-organized non-governmental organization.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Didi Kirsten Tatlow/The New York Times
item.media:description: The headquarters of the China Association for Preservation and Development of Tibetan Culture is in a heavily guarded government building in Beijing.

item.title: After the Death of Their Daughter, a Verdict Looms
item.description: An American couple are awaiting the outcome, scheduled for Thursday in Qatar, of a murder trial in which they are accused in the death of their adopted daughter.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grace and Matthew Huang, whose daughter died in January 2013, during an interview Sunday. A verdict in their murder trial is scheduled for Thursday.

item.title: With Start-Ups, Greeks Make Recovery Their Own Business
item.description: With few opportunities and record unemployment, some Greeks have stopped waiting for those in power to put the country back on its feet.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalie Kontou founded Athens Insiders, which offers tour packages, after she lost her job at a magazine.

item.title: Memo From Sevastopol: In Crimea, Russia Moved to Throw Off the Cloak of Defeat
item.description: In seizing Crimea, Russia made it clear to Washington and its allies that the future of Ukraine and the region will not be decided by the West alone.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military tanks remained inside the Perevalnoye military base in Crimea on Monday. The base now belongs to Russia.

item.title: Ex-President’s Party Concedes Defeat in Maldives Parliamentary Elections
item.description: The loss by Mohamed Nasheed’s Maldivian Democratic Party cleared the way for a coalition led by the country’s new president, Abdulla Yameen.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Global Health: China Reports Gains in Fighting Tuberculosis
item.description: Evidence that a relatively low-tech strategy for combating the disease can work well, if it is rigorously applied.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: The Lede: In Egypt, One Step Up and 529 Steps Back
item.description: Activists in Egypt and abroad were stunned that 529 people were sentenced to death for the murder of a police officer during clashes in Egypt last summer after the military deposed President Mohamed Morsi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Afghans Who Helped the U.S. Fear That Time for Visas Has Run Out
item.description: Workers considered under threat for helping Americans during the war face a shortage of visas, despite efforts to address a backlog of applications.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 24
item.description: World Tuberculosis Day is observed every year on March 24 to raise awareness about the disease.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
